body:
+1
LGTM!
Thank you for quick review. This commit will upload into master branch.
rebased.

@jinossy,
I would liked to append additional patches for rpc codes using netty4. Would you please check these patches?

@ykrips 
Sure, I will review soon
Alright. It will be fixed up soon.
Could anyone review this?
Could you add some example for CREATE TABLE? It may be similar to those of other storage types. Nevertheless, the example would be helpful to users.
Sure. I'll add it.

I've updated the patch as follows:
- Change protobuf fields.
- Add more comments.
- Clean up some methods.

Sorry for late review. 
I 'll review tonight.
How about 'Index written'? I think that just 'written' may be regarded as 'table written' or 'data written'.

The patch looks nice to me. In order to ensure its stability, it would be great if we carry out some experiments with some heavy queries on TB-sized data sets. Anyone can help this kind of experiment?

Actually, I used 'written' as the meaning of 'data written'. 
But, as you said, it would be better if users can see what type of query is finished.
So, I'd like to suggest adding the finished query type as follows.

```
Progress: 100%, response time: 17.758 sec
(0 rows, 17.758 sec, 70.4 MiB written)
CREATE INDEX OK
default>
```

We also can show this kind of message after `CREATE TABLE` or `INSERT` statements.
What do you think?
@hyunsik, it would be a great thing that we can run some stress tests on multiple-node clusters. We need to find out test environment for this test.
+1, ship it!

Sorry for late review.
The latest patch looks good to me.
Here is my +1, but it will be good to wait for Hyunsik's review.
Added an example of the table creation.
No problems. I'll commit it after hyunsik finishes the review.

+1
Thank you @ykrips for this work. I greatly appreciate your effort.

+1
The patch looks great to me. Ship it!

+1
The change looks good to me. This patch seems to be ready to be committed.
I'll finish the review by tomorrow.

@hyunsik, thanks for your work.
With this patch, it seems that users can execute `CREATE TABLE` statements with nested schemas.
So, I simply submitted an example query used in a junit test, but found the following error:

```
default> create table nested_table (f1 int, nested_field record (f2 int4, f3 int8), f3 text);
ERROR: Cannot create table "default.nested_table".
```

The error message is follows:


Wrong merge branch

@jinossy, no problems. :)

+1
Great work!!
Ship it.

I’ve successfully tested by real data on my company cluster.
- ENV
  - 2 TajoMaster + 4 TajoWorker 
  - JDK 1.7.0_67
  - 1G Network

```
Json Table 
2TB compressed by snappy
7.3TB Actual bytes

select count(*) from (select id from table1 group by id) t1;
Progress: 100%, response time: 3546.781 sec
?count
-------------------------------
2802809536
(1 rows, 3546.781 sec, 11 B selected)


Parquet table
8.1TB compressed by snappy
select count(*)  from table2
Progress: 100%, response time: 374.358 sec
?count
-------------------------------
16090817643
(1 rows, 374.358 sec, 12 B selected)
```
+1 LGTM!
@jinossy thanks for the quick review!

+1
I greatly appreciate your effort.
Thank you!

Hi @jihoonson,

I've updated the patch to allow duplicated names in different nested levels. I changed the primary key in catalog stores to TID and ORDINAL_POSITION instead of TID and COLUMN_NAME. Even though DB catalog itself does not guarantee the uniqueness of column names in the same level, the uniqueness is guaranteed by Schema. So, it would be Ok.

I'm sorry for late review. The patch looks good to me. Even though the patch is conflict with the latest revision, the conflict is trivial. So, I tested it easily. 

One suggestion is one column name 'heartbeat. In my view, the 'heartbeat' is slightly ambiguous. I think that it would be better if we use 'last_heartbeat' or 'last_heartbeat_ts'.
That would be good. This column name will be changed in a next commit.

@hyunsik thanks for your comment. 
That was my misunderstanding. I fixed it.
Sorry for late review. I'll review today.

Hi @navis,
Thank you for your contribution. There may be mistake in the title. Could you rename the title? 

In these days, TravisCI has been too slow. There have been many pending pull requests for this reason. So, it would be better if you submit the patch to the jira and mark the jira as PATCH AVAILABLE. Please see this mailing thread too.

http://markmail.org/message/itfwyhcoppqmaouu

@navis Good to see you
The CSVFile will be deprecated. please refer to DelimitedTextFile

+1
The change looks straightforward.
This patch is for TAJO-1369 rather than TAJO-1370. So, I'll change the commit log before committing it.

@hyunsik with the latest patch, the `create table` statement works well.
However, I couldn't see the detailed information of nested columns. Please see the following example.

```
default> create table nested_table (f1 int, nested_field record (f2 int4, f3 int8), f3 text);
OK
default> \d
nested_table
default> \d nested_table

table name: default.nested_table
table path: hdfs://localhost:7020/tajo/warehouse/default/nested_table
store type: CSV
number of rows: 0
volume: 0 B
Options: 
    'text.delimiter'='|'

schema: 
f1  INT4
nested_field    RECORD
f3  TEXT
```

The `nested_field` column is presented as just one record, and details are veiled. It would be much greater if you improve it.

@sirpkt thanks for your work.
I have a couple of comments.
First, `CSVFILE_DELIMITER` is deprecated. If there are any bugs related to `TEXT_DELIMITER`, we must fix it instead of using `CSVFILE_DELIMITER`.
In addition, I have a question about the following your description.

```
Without this, when two tables, one is 'csvfile.delimiter'=';' and the other has no option, are used in the same query, one is set as TEXT_DELIMITER = ';' and the other is set as TEXT_DELIMITER = '|' and compete for the meta option of the Execution block.
```

If only one table is configured with an explicitly different delimiter, two tables must be parsed with different delimiters. If I misunderstand anything, please let me know.

Second, it is hard to unserstand for me why `CSVFILE_DELIMITER` or `TEXT_DELIMITER` is required to store intermediate results. As you know, the default file type of intermediate results is `RAW`, not `CSV` or `TEXT`.
Would you mind explaining more detailed backgrounds?

Hi, @hyunsik, @sirpkt. 
This issue was closed in GitHub, but not in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TAJO-919. 
Could you close that too, please?

+1

The change looks straightforward. Thank you for nice finding.
@jinossy If it will be not deprecated in near future, can we still get some usefulness in this? Fixed test fails, anyway.
I'll review tomorrow.
Could you trigger the unit test?
Could you rebase it? It seems to be conflict to the recent changes.

Hi, @hyunsik. This code is already committed via Jihoon. :) 
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TAJO-1378

The patch looks nice to me. Of course, your work is useful. 

It would be great if this feature is applied to DelimitedTextFile too because DelimitedTextFile is new replacement to CSVFile. DelimitedTextFile's performance is really great. According to some benchmark result, it can parse more than 500MB CSV data sets per second. It also can boost up query response times in many cases, especially I/O intensive workloads.

I think that the work for DelimitedTextFile does not need to be done in this issue. We can do in another jira.

Anyway, could you fix some test failure? It still has one test failure.

@navis 
OK, I've create new jira issue TAJO-1381.
If you fix test failure, we can start review.

Thanks
Fixed test fails

Thank you for your contribution, I ran integer benchmark. but I found performance decrement about 10%
I will upload the benchmark patch to jira. Can you check this ? 
- Original

```
Result: 25611504.825 ±(99.9%) 126889.037 ops/s [Average]
  Statistics: (min, avg, max) = (25290299.861, 25611504.825, 25869540.937), stdev = 169393.233

BenchmarkNumberUtil.unsafeParseIntThroughput  thrpt   25  25611504.825 ± 126889.037  ops/s
```
- Applied your patch

```

BenchmarkNumberUtil.unsafeParseIntThroughput  thrpt   25  22658219.224 ± 190563.440  ops/s
```
It is some difference. Then, we can discard this patch.

@hyunsik, I made some changes in GlobalEngine, especially DDL execution part. They cause some problems with HBaseStorqageManager. I already created an issue (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TAJO-1373). After resolving that issue, I'll trigger again.
+1. Great @navis . It solves my problems.

+1

The fix is straightforward.
Thank you for your work. The patch looks good to me. I leaved one trivial comment.

The patch looks good to me. Thank you Dongjoon for your review. 

It should have to be done. If the unit tests are passed, I'll commit it shortly.

The change looks straightforward. The second patch that eliminates unnecessary path list and unnecessary sort looks much better than the first one.

If all unit tests are passed, I'll finish the review.

This problem causes severe memory consumption problem and performance degradation if queries involve broadcast, especially in high-end servers which allow many task concurrency. I'll review it today night.

+1
I manually verified the patch. It passes 'mvn clean install'.

Thank you for your feedback. No problem. Do you mean the following links? Which one do you prefer?
1. http://apache.org/dyn/closer.cgi/tajo/tajo-0.10.0/tajo-jdbc-0.10.0.jar
2. http://www.us.apache.org/dist/tajo/tajo-0.10.0/tajo-jdbc-0.10.0.jar

By the way, those have a version number in the link, so we should update carefully.
I just meant the title name. The link 'http://tajo.apache.org/downloads.html' would be best because this page can track the number of downloads for each release.

Oh, I see. You mean literally 'Direct Download' instead of 'From Tajo Homepage'.
Okay, I will change soon.
Anyway, cannot reproduce test fail.
Thank you :)

According to my test, it works well. Thank you for your contribution. This is the first trial to put python code to Tajo repository. I'm still considering what the best source tree layout is. I'll review it soon.
Guys, Any idea? If you have no idea, I will discard this patch

Welcome,

We need to keep the code size small. It is very important because the code size is highly relative to the maintenance cost. BTW, this patch includes too many duplicated codes. You should try to find the minimum branch point to suppress code duplicates. 

Please refer this comment. I think that this approach is the best for us.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TAJO-1206?focusedCommentId=14229312
I'll review tomorrow.

Sorry guys, I have been very busy.
I'll restart it shortly. :)

I rebased it. Also, this patch additionally includes the following changes:
- Improved tajo-dump to dump nested schema
- enabled \d command in tsql to show nested schema correctly.

The patch looks good in overall. However, it is difficult to understand details of some changes. 
Would you mind to give me a brief summarization of the changes?
In addition, it would be great if you add some comments.

@ykrips thanks for your patch. I left a comment. 
In addition, it is difficult to understand details of some changes. 
Would you mind telling me a brief summarization of the changes?
Also, it would be great if you add some comments.

+1

Even though I suggested 8000 chars, 4000 chars also look enough. When we face the same problem due to limited length, we need to investigate new solution.

If there are no objection until tomorrow, I'll commit it.
Oh, I updated my pull request here (GitHub) and forgot to upload in Jira issue. I will update the attachement file in Jira issue soon.

Since I did move sql statements to xml files for Oracle and PostgreSQL DBMS, but these deprecated sql files for Oracle and PostgreSQL are still remained. Sorry for that. Can you apply these changes to /tajo-catalog/tajo-catalog-server/src/main/resources/schemas/oracle/oracle.xml and /tajo-catalog/tajo-catalog-server/src/main/resources/schemas/postgresql/postgresql.xml? I will create another issue to delete these deprecated sql files. Without this issue, I don't have any concerns on this patch.
Thank you @ykrips for your comment. I missed them.

@ykrips,

You may be the best reviewer for this issue. Could you review this patch if you are ok?

@jihoonson Sure,
If a right table can broadcast, it does not share memory. so I’ve change to share the right table
In addition, I’ve fix a hidden bugs.
- Fix memory leak
- Add missing property in protobuf idl

Can you tell me lines ? I will be easy to add comments
@jihoonson , Thank you for review on this patch. I will add some comments on this patch, and will upload patches in a short time.

@jinossy thanks for your comment. It is very helpful.
I left some comments for descriptions on classes and a variable.
If a table is broadcasted, it seems that all tasks in a node share the same cache. It would be great if you can give detailed descriptions on this cache mechanism.
Thanks!
Sure. I will review it.

+1
I've manually tested this patch with PostgreSQL. It works well.

+1

the patch looks good to me. I tested the patch in the case where TajoMaster is restarted. It works well. tsql reconnected to TajoMaster and got new session while keeping cached session variables.
I also verified 'mvn clean install'.

I will add comments. 
Thanks
